AUTHORITY TO PROVIDE PRIORITY HEALTH CARE TO VETERANS OF THE PERSIAN GULF WAR. Inpatient care eligibility for veterans exposed to environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War is expanded under title 38, United States Code. Veterans with potential exposure can receive hospital and nursing home care for disabilities even without conclusive medical evidence linking the disability to the exposure. The eligibility for inpatient care for veterans exposed to environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War is expanded under title 38, United States Code. Veterans can receive outpatient care for disabilities before December 31, 1994, even without conclusive medical evidence linking the disability to the exposure. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) of the Act, effective as of August 2, 1990, allow reimbursement for veterans who paid for care due to potential exposure during the Persian Gulf War. Additionally, certain health care authorities are extended, including eligibility for care for exposure to dioxin or ionizing radiation and eligibility for sexual trauma counseling. The amendments extend eligibility for sexual trauma counseling and adjust deadlines for various programs under title 38, United States Code. SEC. 3. SHARING OF RESOURCES WITH STATE HOMES. (a) Purpose.--Section 8151 of title 38, United States Code, is amended to improve care for veterans by allowing the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities for sharing health-care resources. 
(b) Definition.--Section 8152 of the same title is amended to include hospital care, medical services, and rehabilitative services as health-care resources. 
(c) Sharing of Health-Care Resources.--Section 8153(a) is amended to allow agreements for mutual use of health-care resources. The Secretary can make agreements with State veterans facilities to share specialized medical resources and healthcare resources, as long as it avoids duplication or underutilization of Department resources allocated for veterans' care.
